snippet: Using a series of spring-loaded, oarlike paddles on their back legs, the insects are skilled at jumping from the surface of water, researchers report.
abstract: Study in journal Current Biology shows that pygmy mole crickets, tiny insects that live in burrows near fresh water in warm places, are able to jump form surface of water using oarlike paddles on their back legs.
lead_paragraph: Using a series of spring-loaded, oarlike paddles on their back legs, the insects are skilled at jumping from the surface of water, researchers report.

headline.print_headline: Jumping Insects Can Push Off Water’s Surface
headline.seo: Pygmy Mole Crickets Can Jump From Water’s Surface
headline.main: Jumping Insects Can Push Off Water’s Surface
